occurrences.line_text: Who her despysd (ah who would her despyse?)
Who sore against his will did him retaine,
Who for the proofe of his great puissance,
Who playing on his harpe, vnto him drew
Who thither with her came, to learne and see
Who now was falne into new languishment
It to reueale: who still her answered, there was nought.
Apollo came; who soone as he had sought
Who was the root and worker of her woe:
Read therefore who it is, which this hath wrought,
Who reading it with inward loathfulnesse,
Who soone as he beheld that angels face,
For who so list into the heauens looke,
Who all the West with equall conquest wonne,
Who in his hand an yron flale did hould,
He askt, who had that Dame so fouly dight;
The which another did, who now is fled with shame.
Who was it then (sayd Artegall) that wrought?
His yron page, who him pursew'd so light,
Who full of scorne to be commaunded so,
Who mou'd no more therewith, then when a rocke
Who with sterne countenance and indignant pride
But looke who does dissent from this my read,
Who when he saw it bootelesse to resist,
Who now to perils great for iustice sake proceedes.
Who all that comes doth take, and therewith fill
Who as they to the passage gan to draw,
But there the Paynim, who that vse well knew
Who being entred, nought did then auaile
Who rudely hayld her forth without remorse,
Who being freed from Proteus cruell band
Who all this while behind him did remaine,
Who came not forth, but for Sir Artegall
All which when Artegall, who all this while
Who round about her tender wast it fitted well.
Who all that piteous storie, which befell
Shapt like a horses shoe, who list to seeke it there.
Who ouertaking him did disaray,
Who so vpon him selfe will take the skill
Who hauing lately left that louely payre,
Who taking her from me, his owne loue left astray.
That who he was, vneath was to descry;
Who with few sowces of his yron flale,
Who more then losse of life ydreaded it;
But who can scape, what his owne fate hath wrought?
Descried streight; who all the citty warned,
Who yesterday droue vs to such distresse,
Who, as he could, them goodly well did greete,
Who had him seene, imagine mote thereby,
Moue Radigund? who though she still haue worne
Who will not stoupe with good, shall be made stoupe with harme.
who seekes her to entrap.
Who when he nigh approcht, shee mote arede
Who though desirous rather to rest mute,
Who as she nigh vnto them drew, the one
Of highest Ioue, who doth true iustice deale
Who well perceiuing, how her wand she shooke,
Therefore thus one of them, who seem'd in sight
Who long before awoke (for she ful ill
Who shortly must repent that now so vainely brauest.
Who when him selfe now well recur'd did see,
Who still from him as fast away did flie,
Who seeing her approch gan forward set,
Who seeing him come still so fiercely on,
Which when the Damzell, who those deadly ends
Who counsels him through confidence of might,
Who bringing them to their appointed place,
Like to the Thracian Tyrant, who they say
She warn'd the knights thereof: who thereupon
Who whilest in hand it gryping hard he hent,
His name hight Order, who commaunding peace,
Who sate on high, that she might all men see,
Who bowing low before her Maiestie,
Who priuie was, and partie in the case:
Abhorred Murder, who with bloudie knyfe
Who then can thee, Mercilla, throughly prayse,
Of that great Ladie, who with goodly chere
Who them to their posterities doe still declare.
Sent by their mother, who a widow was,
By a strong Tyrant, who inuaded has
Her name was Belgï¿½, who in former age
Euen seuenteene goodly sonnes; which who had seene
Who after that his monstrous father fell
Who when he none of all those knights did see
Who gaue him roiall giftes and riches rare,
By her strong foe, who had defaced cleene
Who then can thinke their hedlong ruine to recure.
Who from his saddle swarued nought asyde,
Who with right humble thankes him goodly greeting,
Who all that wrong vnto that wofull Dame
Who with a cloud of night him couering, bore
Who nought was terrifide, but greater courage tooke.
With Belge, who watcht all this while full sad,
Who hauing left Mercilla, streight way went
Who through his yeares long since aside had set
Who her imprisond hath, and her life often sought.
To him for aide, who long in vaine their rage withstands.
And who he was, and what those villaines were,
O who may not with gifts and words be tempted?
Who when he gaue me armes, in field to fight,
Who flocking round about them, as a swarme
Who for like cause faire Belge did oppresse,
And so be now Grantorto, who no lesse
Who came at length, with proud presumpteous gate,
Who streight her leading with meete maiestie
Who when they nigh approching, had espyde
And him forbidden, who his heast obserued.
Ne none can find, but who was taught them by the Muse.
Who whenas each of other had a sight,
Who seeing him from farre, with piteous sound
His name is Crudor, who through high disdaine
Who executes her wicked will, with worse despight.
Who hearkning to that voice, him selfe vpreard,
Who as he still decayd, so he encreased more.
He was ymett, who with vncomely shame
Who scornes thy ydle scoffe, and bids thee be defyde.
Who through stro[n]g powre had now her self in hould,
Who seeing, in what daunger he was plast,
Who hath not learnd him selfe first to subdew:
Who will not mercie vnto others shew,
Who comming forth yet full of late affray,
I chaunst to meete this knight, who there lyes slaine,
Who euer thinkes through confidence of might,
Who ere he thence had traueild many a mile,
Who when he saw his sonne so ill bedight,
Which dwelt thereby, who sought her to affy
But lou'd this fresh young Knight, who dwelt her ny,
Fearelesse, who ought did thinke, or ought did say,
The cause of all this euill, who was slaine
Of a discourteous Knight, who her had reft,
Who with the horrour of her haplesse care
Who was more light of foote and swift in chace,
Who nathelesse, when he the Lady saw
Who to him aunswer'd, that there was no place
Who sitting with his Lady then at bord,
His life attonce; who nought could do, but shun
Behinde his Ladies backe, who to him cryde,
Vpon him ran; who being well prepard,
Who hauing now no vse of his long speare,
Who euer, as he saw him nigh succeed,
The wife of bold Sir Bruin, who is Lord
To that foule feend, who dayly doth attend
Quite ouerthrow, who now ginnes to despize
Who thinkes from me his sorrow all doth rize.
Who her together with his Squyre
Who though he were still in this desert wood,
Who when as now long time he lacked had
Who through thicke woods and brakes & briers him drew,
Who seeing one in so great daunger set
Who it perceiuing, hand vpon him layd,
Who to them stepping did them soone diuide,
Who both in minde, the which most grieueth me,
Who whether he aliue be to be found,
And eke this Squire, who likewise wounded was
Who can him cure, that will be cur'd of none?
Who when on ground they saw their fellow slaine,
Who hearing how his people badly sped,
Who when he once his dreadfull strokes had tasted,
Who flying still did ward, and warding fly away.
Who now come to himselfe, yet would not rize,
Who rising vp at last in ghastly wize,
With her vnworthy knight, who ill him entertayned.
Who nathelesse not therewith satisfyde,
Who notwithstanding that in former fight
What cared she, who sighed for her sore,
Or who did wayle or watch the wearie night?
The sonne of Venus who is myld by kynd,
Who though she were with wearinesse nigh dead,
This was Disdaine, who led that Ladies horse
Was Scorne, who hauing in his hand a whip,
Who from the high degree of happy state,
Who after thraldome of the gentle Squire,
Who therewith flesht, vpon him set anew,
Who mocketh all my paine, & laughs the more I mourn.
Who was not able vp him selfe to reare,
Was holpen vp, who him supported standing neare.
Who was so far from being ought amazed,
Who all this while stood there beside them bound,
Of faire Serena, who as earst you heard,
Who all this while endured for her sake,
Who her admiring as some heauenly wight,
Who him besought himselfe to disattyre,
That who had seene him then, would haue bethought
Which seeing Coridon, who her likewise
Who on the other side did seeme so farre
Who now does follow the foule Blatant Beast,
For who had tasted once (as oft did he)
Poore Colin Clout (who knowes not Colin Clout?)
All saue the shepheard, who for fell despight
Who can aread, what creature mote she bee,
Who rashly sought that, which I mote not see.
Who scarcely yet from former feare exempted,
Who in the couert of the night, that none
Who being now in dreadfull darknesse layd,
That who so heares her heauinesse, would rew
Were brought vnto their Captaine, who was set
That who so hardie hand on her doth lay,
Who in the horror of the griesly night,
That who them sees, would wonder at their fray,
And who sees not, would be affrayd to heare:
Who minding more her safety then himselfe,
Fayre Pastorell, who with the selfe same wound
Who sighing sore, as if her hart in twaine
Of many worst, who with vnkind disdaine
Who when he backe returned from the wood,
Who as he vnto him approched nye,
Where Pastorell? who full of fresh dismay,
Who all this while at will did range and raine,
Who whylome was in his youthes freshest flowre
Who as her owne it nurst, and named euermore.
Who in a morning, when this Mayden faire
Who euer is the mother of one chylde,
Who ioyning ioy with her in one accord,
Of Calidore; who seeking all this while
Who now no place besides vnsought had left,
Who nathemore his heauy load releast,
Who hath endur'd the whole, can beare each part.
Then gan the Dwarfe the whole discourse declare,
The whole atchieuement of this doubtfull warre,
So gan he to discourse the whole debate,
My whole desire hath beene, and yet is now,
It might breake out, and set the whole on fire,
But twixt the other twaine his kingdome whole did shaire.
And the whole family therewith adred,
Madnesse to saue a part, and lose the whole.
And all her whole creation did her shew
And that vile Hag, all were her whole delight
To see his whole yeares labour lost so soone,
Emongst the Angels, a whole legione
That is the whole worlds commune remedy.
They two enough t'encounter an whole Regiment.
The whole discourse of his captiuance sad,
Her minde was whole possessed of one thought,
Then gan she to declare the whole discourse
The worlds whole rule for Cleopatras sight.
Of whom we may at will the whole occasion know.
That no whole peece of him was to be seene,
Though nothing whole, but all to brusd and broken,
The whole occasion of his late misfare,
His whole exploite, and valorous emprize,
Whole to commit, and to his dealing iust.
Recured well, and made him whole againe:
Made in his tender flesh, but whole them all he found.
So now she had bene wandring two whole yeares
And wholesome Statutes to her husband brought;
But presently was voide and wholly vaine:
And thee abandond wholly doe possesse,
On which their eies and harts were wholly set,
The feeble senses wholly did confound,
For very gall, that rather wholly dead
But she, whose hart to loue was wholly lent,
But wholy wast, and void of peoples trode,
That she her loue and hart hath wholy sold
Therefore her selfe she wholy recommended
Whom that most noble Briton Prince so long
Whom to auenge, she had this Knight from far co[m]peld.
A monster vile, whom God and man does hate:
Deuoure their dam; on whom while so he gazd,
His foes haue slaine themselues, with whom he should contend.
And vnto Morpheus comes, whom drowned deepe
Her, whom he waking euermore did weene,
You, whom my hard auenging destinie
And that false other Spright, on whom he spred
Whom suddenly he wakes with fearefull frights,
He so vngently left her, whom she loued best.
The wretched woman, whom vnhappy howre
To loue this gentle Lady, whom ye see,
With whom as once I rode accompanyde,
For fairest Vnaes sake, of whom I sing,
To whom approching she to her gan call,
With whom he whoredome vsd, that few did know,
Whom ouertaking, they gan loudly bray,
Whom seeing such, for dread he durst not show
Before her stands her knight, for whom she toyld so sore.
From whom her booteth not at all to flie;
Was like the person selfe, whom he did beare:
Most wretched wight, whom nothing might suffise,
Whom great griefe made forget the raines to hold
Whom broad awake she finds, in troublous fit,
His worthy shield, whom he with guilefull snare
Whom false Duessa saues, and for
Whom all the people follow with great glee,
Whom when she found, as she him left in plight,
More old then Ioue, whom thou at first didst breede,
O welcome child, whom I haue longd to see,
Whom hauing softly disarayd of armes,
Of whom he learned had in secret wise
Whom saluage nation does adore,
Whom when the raging Sarazin espide,
Of whom he meanes his bloudie feast to make,
Whom till to ryper yeares he gan aspire,
Her children deare, whom he away had wonne:
Walkt in that forest, whom he had not taught
Faire Vna: whom when Satyrane espide,
Whom all so soone as that proud Sarazin
The forlorne Maiden, whom your eyes haue seene
Of doughtie knights, whom Faery land did raise,
An heard of Bulles, whom kindly rage doth sting,
He lightly left the foe, with whom he fought,
Whom when his maistresse proud perceiu'd to fall,
Whom when the Prince, to battell new addrest,
Whom these sad eyes saw nigh vnto deaths dore,
Whom great Orgoglio with his puissaunce fell
Were housed therewithin, whom he enlargen might.
Whom when his Lady saw, to him she ran
The chearelesse man, whom sorrow did dismay,
Whom Redcrosse knight withstands.
Whom hardly he from flying forward stayd,
And eke from whom make ye this hasty flight:
From whom returning sad and comfortlesse,
That cursed wight, from whom I scapt whyleare,
Iwote (quoth he) whom triall late did teach,
With whom in all abuse thou hast thy selfe defilde?
Whom well she knew to spring from heauenly race,
Whom thus recouer'd by wise Patience,
Whom still she fed, whiles they were weake & young,
To whom the carefull charge of him she gaue,
Ne car'd to hoord for those, whom he did breede:
Whom highly he did reuerence and adore,
For thou emongst those Saints, whom thou doest see,
Whom all a Faeries sonne doen nominate?
Whom I from far see on the walles appeare
Whom famous Poetes verse so much doth vaunt,
Whom fyrie steele now burnt, that earst him arm'd,
Whom so dismayd when that his foe beheld,
Whom when the damned feend so fresh did spy,
Whom rauenous hunger did thereto constraine:
Whom farre before did march a goodly band
Whom all admired, as from heauen sent,
To whom the Redcrosse knight this answere sent,
Whom if ye please for to discouer plaine,
As chained Beare, whom cruell dogs do bait,
In whom great rule of Temp'raunce goodly doth appeare.
Whom Princes late displeasure left in bands,
Whom his victorious hands did earst restore
Whom late I left in langourous constraint?
Witnesse ye heaue[n]s, whom she in vaine to helpe did call.
But thou, sweet Babe, whom frowning froward fate
Whom when the good Sir Guyon did behold,
This lucklesse child, whom thus ye see with bloud defild.
Whom when I heard to beene so ill bestad,
Whom thus at gaze, the Palmer gan to bord
Ne ought he car'd, whom he endamaged
By tortious wrong, or whom bereau'd of right.
Whom they in equall pray hope to deuide,
Whom raging windes threatning to make the pray
Mongst whom on me she deigned to bestowe
To whom auaunting in great brauery,
Whom all the people decke with girlands greene,
Of Amazons, whom Pyrrhus did destroy,
To whom she thus; but ere her words ensewed,
To whom he thus: ï¿½ fairest vnder skie,
Whom sore he bett, and gor'd with many a wound,
And where he hits, nought knowes, & whom he hurts, nought cares.
His burning eyen, whom bloudie strakes did staine,
Whom that mad man of life nigh late depriu'd,
Whom when as he perceiued to respire,
With whom from tender dug of commune nourse,
Most ioyous man, on whom the shining Sunne,
That Ladie whom I had to me assynd,
Whom he had feignd th'abuser of my loue to bee.
But weend it was my loue, with whom he playd.
Till this mad man, whom your victorious might
His be that care, whom most it doth concerne,
Then loe, where bound she sits, who[m]; thou hast sought,
Of whom sore hurt, for his reuenge
Whom Guyon seeing stoup, pursewed fast
Vnto his brother, whom Cymochles men did call.
Whom then she does transforme to mo[n]strous hewes,
Whom bold Cymochles trauelling to find,
Whom neither wind out of their seat could forse,
Whom should he, but his owne deare Lord, there see,
And whom I lust, do heape with glory and renowne?
By whom they passing, spake vnto them nought.
Whom all that folke with such contention,
Whom he had long time sought with fruitlesse suit:
Of whom high Ioue wont whylome feasted bee,
Whom Arthur soone hath reskewed
In Mammons house, the Palmer, whom whyleare
Whom when the Palmer saw, abasht he was
Whom when Pyrrochles saw, inflam'd with rage,
To whom the Palmer fearelesse answered;
Whom fortune hath alreadie laid in lowest seat.
To whom Cymochles said; For what art thou,
And now the other, whom he earst did daunt,
Whom foe with double battry doth assaile,
Whom when the Palmer saw in such distresse,
As saluage Bull, whom two fierce mastiues bayt,
But as a man, whom hellish feends haue frayd,
But when the Palmer, whom he long ygoe
And said, Deare sir, whom wandring to and fro
Firme is thy faith, whom daunger neuer fro me drew.
To whom the Infant thus, Faire Sir, what need
Besiegd of many foes, whom straunger
Whom gracious lot, and thy great valiaunce
Whom when the knights beheld, they gan dispose
To whom the Prince in curteous manner said;
Not he, whom Greece, the Nourse of all good arts,
Whom Alma hauing shewed to her guestes,
Of mightie GÃ¶emot, whom in stout fray
Mongst whom he parted his imperiall state,
Of whom it hight; but in the end their Sire
Mongst whom his realme he equally decreed
After whom Lago, and Kinmarke did raine,
Whom he at sea found wandring from their wayes,
Next whom Morindus did the crowne sustaine,
Of hardy Nennius, whom he yet did slay,
With whom she marched streight against her foes,
Whom antique history so high doth raise,
So made them victours, whom he did subdew.
With whom king Coyll made an agreement,
Of whom he did great Constantine beget,
Whom Romane warres, which now foure hundred yeares,
For dread of whom, and for those Picts annoyes,
Of Saxons, whom he for his safetie imployes.
A goodly creature, whom he deemd in mind
Of whom all Faeryes spring, and fetch their lignage right.
Whom soone as that vnruly rablement,
Whom to pursue, the Infant after hide,
And as a Beare whom angry curres haue touzd,
Whom still he marked freshly to arize
By whom a litle skippet floting did appeare.
Whom ouertaking, she in merry sort
Whom nought regarding, they kept on their gate,
Beene suncke, of whom no memorie did stay:
Huge Ziffius, whom Mariners eschew
Of whom they ouer-comen, were depriu'd
T'allure weake trauellers, whom gotten they did kill.
And Orcus tame, whom nothing can perswade,
Not that celestiall powre, to whom the care
That is our Selfe, whom though we do not see,
Whom passing by she happened to meet:
Whom such when Guyon saw, he drew him neare,
Here wonnes Acrasia, whom we must surprise,
With a new Louer, whom through sorceree
As in their mistresse reskew, whom they lad;
Whom this Enchauntresse hath transformed thus,
To whom the Palmer thus, The donghill kind
Whom straunge aduenture did from Britaine fet,
Whom they found sitting on a sumptuous bed,
Whom when the Lady saw so faire a wight.
With whom he meant to make his sport & courtly play.
Whom hauing laid in comfortable couch,
To whom no share in armes and cheualrie
Whom fortune for her husband would allot,
Whom long he lou'd, for him in hast did send,
Whom thy good fortune, hauing fate obayd,
The man whom heauens haue ordaynd to bee
Octa and Oza, whom he lately brake
And our weake hands (whom need new strength shall teach)
There he this knight of her begot, whom borne
Whom late in chace of beautie excellent
His Faery Queene, for whom he did complaine:
Of whom he asked, whence he lately came,
Of whom ye seeke to be most magnifide:
To whom the Prince; Dwarfe, comfort to thee take,
For whom he wondrous pensiue grew in mind,
To succour wretched wights, whom we captiued see.
Of life, whom late their Ladies arrow ryu'd:
To her, to whom the heauens do serue and sew?
To whom in perfect loue, and spotlesse fame,
Mongst whom might be, that he did closely lye,
To whom halfe weeping, she thus answered,
Whom when as Venus saw so sore displeased,
To whom sweet Poets verse hath giuen endlesse date.
Then her owne daughter Pleasure, to whom shee
To whom her louing hart she linked fast
Whom with his brethren Timias slew, befell:
And hurt far off vnknowne, whom euer she enuide.
Whom such whenas the wicked Hag did vew,
Whom when the fearefull Damzell nigh espide,
Whom she did meane to make the thrall of her desire.
Whom when as nigh approching she espyde,
Whom he had reskewed from captiuaunce
To whom approching, well he mote perceiue
Whom so she fittest finds to serue her lust,
But that bold knight, whom ye pursuing saw
That gentle Lady, whom I loue and serue,
Whom I in countrey cottage found by chaunce;
This gentle Damzell, whom I wrote vpon,
Of her rich spoyles, whom he had earst destroyd,
It was her selfe, whom it did imitate,
She was the Lady selfe, whom he so long had sought.
It was, with whom in company he yode,
The virgin, whom he had abusde so sore:
To whom I leuell all my labours end,
Another knight, whom tempest thither brought,
Then Paridell, in whom a kindly pryde
Whom Venus to him gaue for meed of worthinesse.
Whom for remembraunce of her passed ioy,
From whom I Paridell by kin descend;
For that same Brute, whom much he did aduaunce
Whom hauing slaine, through luckles arrowes glau[n]ce
Whom he through wearie wars and labours long,
And his faire wife, whom honest long he kept vneath.
Whom she hath vow'd to dub a faire Cucquold.
Whom, to be Paridell he did deuize;
Whom such when as Malbecco spyed clere,
Of whom a knight, no knight at all perdee,
But went his way; whom when he passed kend,
